In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

You can use the following code to implement the requested function:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    filtered = filter((manufacturer, model) -> manufacturer == "audi" && (model == "a4" || model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    new_col = repeat([true], length(filtered))
    filtered[:audi_a4_type] = new_col
    return filtered
end
```

This function takes a DataFrame `df_cars` as input and filters it down to only include rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column named `audi_a4_type` and sets all values in this column to `true` using the `repeat()` function, which repeats an array for the desired number of times. Finally, it returns the filtered DataFrame with the new column added.
